metadata.case_name: Heirs of Santokhi Jha v. Purchasers (Defendants 1st Party)

facts.text: Santokhi Jha became owner of the entire raiyati interest in 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza Chhatahara, District of Santhal Parganas many years ago.
Santokhi Jha purchased by registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was the raiyat.
On May 15, 1935, these lands were sold by the 2nd party defendants and others including plaintiffs 1 to 6 to the present appellants (defendants first party).

Plaintiffs (successors in interest of Santokhi Jha) filed suit for declaration and delivery of possession claiming no interest passed to vendees because raiyati character existed and was inalienable under Regulation III of 1872; transfer fraudulent, collusive, no legal necessity.
Defendants first party denied fraud or collusion; pleaded sale for legal necessity to pay antecedent debts; lands were Bakasht lands of the Malik, not raiyati on date of sale.

Subordinate Judge, Dumka held sale justified by legal necessity, not fraudulent; plaintiffs not estopped but bound; land did not retain raiyati character after Santokhi acquired landlord's interest; dismissed suit.
District Judge, Santhal Parganas affirmed trial court findings and dismissal.

Patna High Court (Banerjee J.): Raiyati interest continued despite acquisition of landlord's interest; no merger; Bakasht Malik entry not conflicting with earlier raiyati entry; sale void re raiyati interest; allowed appeal.
Letters Patent Appeal by defendants 1st party dismissed; High Court agreed raiyati interest continued; granted certificate under s.110 CPC and Art.135 Constitution.

In 1909 Settlement Objection Case No.41, Santokhi objected to record of rights entry; stated he purchased Zamindari interest three years ago; wanted village made Khas, his jote as Bakasht Malik; approved by Settlement Officer.
Earlier settlement records showed lands held by Santokhi as raiyat; later records as Bakasht Malik.

Background: Santhal Parganas village community system; raiyats have preferential/reversionary rights; headman (Pradhan) settles lands to jamabandi raiyats; policy against alienation of raiyati lands since 1887, amended Reg III 1872 s.27.

legal_issues.text: If a raiyat of lands in Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlord's interest, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming superior landlord?
Whether the doctrine of merger applies to raiyati interests in Santhal Parganas upon acquisition of superior interest.
Whether the 1935 sale transferred the raiyati interest, given s.27 Reg III 1872.
Civil court jurisdiction vs. exclusive remedy under s.27(3) Reg III 1872.

petitioner_arguments.text: After Santokhi acquired Lakhirajdar's interest, he ceased to be a raiyat: automatic merger of lesser in greater estate; or option exercised to merge.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: English common law merger (Blackstone); equity intention

petitioner_arguments.text: Subsequent record of rights entry 'Bakasht Malik' prevails over earlier raiyati entry; negates raiyati character.
1909 Settlement Officer decision operates as res judicata.
Whether raiyati interest continued is pure question of fact; lower courts found it ceased; High Court could not interfere in second appeal.
Civil court has no jurisdiction; only Deputy Commissioner under s.27(3) Reg III 1872 can evict.

respondent_arguments.text: Raiyati interest continued despite acquisition of superior interest; no merger; Bakasht Malik entry not conflicting.
Raiyat bound to keep raiyati interest separate due to village community interests.
No evidence of intention to merge by Santokhi.

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of merger: Union of interests does not automatically merge; requires clear intention; courts presume no merger if against interest or duty to keep separate; considers conduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Indian law influenced by English equity; no automatic merger.

court_reasoning.text: Special features in Santhal Parganas: Village community rights, Pradhan duties, policy against alienation (Reg III 1872 s.27); raiyat has no right to end raiyati interest; prima facie no merger applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interests of community and Pradhan make it obligatory to keep raiyati intact.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence Santokhi intended merger; Ex.I prayer for Bakasht Malik records cultivation by owner, not negation of raiyati; to Santokhi's benefit and duty to keep separate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Raiyati interest did not merge; continued side by side.

court_reasoning.text: Bakasht Malik means 'in the cultivating possession of landlords, but not privileged'; neutral re raiyati continuance; no conflict with earlier entries; no res judicata issue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entry does not negate raiyati status.

court_reasoning.text: Question of merger/r continuance is mixed question of law and fact; High Court could review.
s.27(2) Reg III obliges civil courts to ignore invalid transfers; not barred by s.27(3).

holdings.text: Raiyati interest did not merge in proprietary interest upon acquisition by Santokhi; continued to exist.
1935 sale void with respect to raiyati interest as right to transfer not recorded in record of rights.
Civil court has jurisdiction to declare invalid transfer under Reg III s.27; not exclusive to Deputy Commissioner.

precedents_cited.relevance: Doctrine of merger does not apply to mofussil lands; Zamindar can hold patni without merger.
Merger if conduct shows no intention to keep interests distinct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Kissen Dutt Ram v. Raja Mumtaz Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Possibility of merger of resumable birt in superior interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surja Narain Mandal v. Nand Lall Sinha
Promotha Nath Roy v. Kishore Lal Sinha
Dakshavani Dasi v. Amrita Lal Ghosh

precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption against merger if duty/interest to keep separate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarda Devi v. Ram Louchan Bhagat
precedents_cited.relevance: Landlord can transfer his interest in raiyati holding; but not raiyati interest.
Later entry prevails in specific facts; Bakasht not always negation of raiyati.

statutes_cited.name: Regulation III of 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits transfer of raiyati holding unless recorded; courts ignore invalid transfers; DC may evict but not exclusive.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory merger provisions; no application here.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Tenancy Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory merger provisions; extended to Bihar but no application.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court: raiyati interest continued unmerged; 1935 sale void as to raiyati interest (no transfer right recorded); only superior rent-receiving right passed to purchasers.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that sale void re raiyati interest (affirming High Court decree to plaintiffs/respondents)

key_quotes.text: "If a raiyat of lands in the District of Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlords interest, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming a superior landlord?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Our conclusion therefore is that the raiyati interest did not merge in the proprietary interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No transfer in contravention of sub-section (1) shall be registered, or shall be in any way recognised as valid by any court..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Reg III s.27(2); basis for invalidity and court duty.

key_quotes.text: "the High Court was right in holding that the sale of May 15, 1935 was void with respect to the raiyati interest"
key_quotes.speaker: court
